event.description: Scott Cramer and company clobber B-town with a roster of visiting talent, guest DJs and late-night weirdos. Tonight's event includes a vogue-off to benefit children in need.

Even non-Germans will feel nostalgia for old Chicago here. Items include wood carvings once owned by the Oscar Mayer family, objects from the Columbian Exposition's Deutsches Haus, and ephemera from dozens of landmark venues, including St. Boniface Church and the Schoenhofen Brewery.

Saxophonist Boney James wasn't the first person to fuze jazz with “urban” music and hip-hop, but he certainly was one of the first jazz players to do it. Then again, his idea of “hip-hop” falls firmly under the weak fuzak end of the musical spectrum. James is mostly about keeping it smooth, as demonstrated by his most recent album, Send One Your Loveâ€”a disc of quiet-storm grooves.

text.content: Metra: Union Pacific NW to Arlington Heights

If hoity-toity spas rub you the wrong way, this low-key alternative may be for you. Housed in a remodeled vintage apartment, the space is more akin to a relaxing holistic home than a clinic. Choose from basic services such as manicures and facials, or go for a reiki treatment or seaweed body facial. Our pick: the Siddha Body Detoxification massage ($150), which starts with a brisk dry brushing of skin, progresses to a full-body wrap and head-to-toe massage, and concludes with you practically melting on the table.

Call it the land of unforgettable toys: this East Village store teems with designer playthings like plush Uglydolls ($25), vinyl Qee figures by Dalek ($30), and fuzzy Shawnimals ($10-25) by local designer Shawn Smith. Although there’s plenty of eye candy for the rugrats, the grown-up crowd will appreciate saucier finds like a cigarette-puffing cat who blows real smoke ($30).
text.author: Annie Tomlin

text.content: By day it’s home to dedicated regulars, by night it’s packed with rock & rollers drinking $5 half pitchers and nodding to free live bands. Pool, darts and Golden Tee are all free, and so is the chance to mark your territory by painting a ceiling tile. If you’re in search of (semitarnished) gold, this is your treasure. this is extra text.

Bring your aches, pains and chronic conditions to the Healing Room, where clinically trained therapist Ellen Letten oversees a team of clinical massage therapists who help relieve pain and provide relaxation. Specialties include trigger point treatment (said to reduce pain), Bach Flower Therapy (homeopathic stress management), cranial sacral therapy, and pregnancy and hot stone massage.

text.content: See where the international adventures of this lit-class favorite originated. The irascible master came into the world in a Victorian Queen Anneâ€“style home in 1899. Though the author was oft quoted referring to the near west suburb as “a place of wide lawns and narrow minds,” proud local devotees celebrated the centennial of his birth by completely restoring the space to better reflect Hemingway’s formative years. Look at original furnishings and photos, then, at the museum, about two blocks away at 200 N Oak Park Ave, find out more and pick up Hemingway books, tote bags and postcards.

text.content: Enjoy tropical relaxation courtesy of Brazilian native and former Urban She waxing goddess Cleise Gomes at her Lincoln Park outpost. Facials, nail services, body wraps and scrubs are all on the menu, but bikini waxing is the spa’s specialty. Choose from the regular ($35), the flirtatious ($50) or the Carecona ($65 and up)â€”a bareâ€“all bikini bonanza.

Join the degree-seeking undergrads and some of the city's most dedicated professionals as a “community student” in advanced morning modern dance class, or sign up for a beginning course in the dance style of your choice.

A traditional â€˜old money’ stomping ground favored by Chicago socialites and celebrities, this stately icon exudes old-school style, with velvet seats in elevators, bowls of fresh fruit lining check-in desk and enormous chandeliers. Feels a bit like crashing a rich aunt’s downtown condo, yet some parts of hotel are a bit tired.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces for guests using internet in rooms & $6.95/hr for nonusers; $12.95-16.95 via cable in rooms).

This spa has elected to focus entirely on the art of massage, and the approach has worked famously. The offerings are broad and largely Eastern-based, though the standby Swedish and sports massages are available. If you’ve never put your feet in the hands of an experienced reflexologist, do yourself a favor. Each part of the foot correlates to a part of the body, and the reflexologist can “read” your feet as though she is reviewing your medical chart. After each inch of the foot is massaged to release toxins, you’ll be sent on your way a little more respectful of the power your tootsies wield.

The local landmark contains a smattering of artists’ studios open to the public Saturdays and Sundays from 1â€“6pm and the first Friday night of each month from 6â€“10pm. Resident artists’ work can be seen in the Bank of America branch on the ground floor, which still hopes to be forgiven for replacing the beloved coffee shop Filter.

Relaxation is dished out Big Easy-style at this Edgewater day spa. With exposed brick, wrought-iron balconies and a waiting area reminiscent of a New Orleans courtyard garden, this retreat oozes Southern hospitality. Keep the mood going with specialty services like the Mint Julep Manicure ($40) or Pedicure ($60) or immerse yourself in a fresh flowerâ€“enhanced milk bath ($45) in a stunning, sunken hydrotherapy tub. A full menu of services for men and women is available, with discounts for those who prepay or sign up for the Spa Select Membership.

text.content: This is Wicker Park’s latest starter clubâ€”basically the bridge between college bars and real nightclubs. The engaging designâ€”think a sexed-up, futuristic hunting lodgeâ€”sets high expectations, which the clumsy service and inconsistent deejaying don’t meet. It’ll be a while before this one can run with the big dogs.

address.cross_streets: between Paulina St and Ashland Ave

text.content: The new location of this much-loved DJ-oriented bar is in a slick, modern space that allows for a decent amount of dancing. It’s got a nice bottled-beer selection but it hasn’t gone chichi. The DJ programming is heavy on high-quality drum ’n’ bass with steady house, techno and electro gigs.

text.content: As its name suggests, this salon/spa is strictly for the guys, but it's located right in the heart of Boystownâ€”so it's a touch more fabulous than other men-only spas. The small space, where stylists cut hair ($15 and up) may be full of soothing brown leather tones, but the real soothing area is the facial room off to the side. The Anti-Aging Treatment ($80) uses a papaya mask that rejuvenates skin while you listen to soft music. We suspect this room isn't comfortable all the time, though, since it's also the same space where the “manscaping” takes place. Who knows, though, in such a calming environment, even a thong wax ($70) might be bearable.

The rock ’n’ roll aspect is toned down in the guestrooms, where amenities include flat-screen TVs and a selection of Aveda toiletries. The hotel occupies the beautiful 40-story Carbide & Carbon Building, an art deco superstar built in 1929 by sons of famed architect Daniel Burnham.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces & in rooms).

The second location of His Stuff is double the size of the original, which means the new outpost has more clothing and shoes to choose from by guy-friendly designers such as J Lindeberg, Modern Amusement and 7 Diamonds.

Grab a Gentle Fawn top ($36) to wear over Buffalo jeans ($42), pick from a wide selection of dangly Clara Beau earrings ($24), and pull it all together with a cheery vinyl tote by Queen Bee ($56).

text.content: Nourhy’s cottage-esque studio in Bucktown (plus the presence of her pooch) disarms clients even before she employs her light, practiced touch to her reflexology, massage, and craniosacral treatments. Nourhy uses organic sheets, towels and oils and has an intuitive knowledge of what the client needs: She blended several treatments for us, and our stress levelsâ€”not to mention our shouldersâ€”dropped immediately and stayed that way for days.
Metra: Elec to Millennium Station. El: Green, Brown, Orange, Purple (rush hrs) to Madison. Bus: 3, 4, 6, 14, 147, 151

Complimentary snacks and cocoa, a foot soak with every treatment, and a personal welcome from owner and nine-year industry veteran Audrie Mumphery are a few of the little details that make this second-floor, 4,000-square-foot spa feel more like a friend’s apartment than a busy Loop business. Choose from a traditional assortment of facials, body wraps, massages, manicures and pedicures. Signature treatments include the detoxifying and moisturizing Green Tea Facial ($95) and the hydrating Lemon Cream Pedicure ($55).

This adorable Wicker Park spa focuses on facials. Your treatment begins with questions about how often you’re outside, and what hair, skin-care and makeup products you use. Your therapist uses this info to blend products from the all-natural skin-care line from Hungary called Ã‰minence. For example, sweat-clogged pores are cleansed with a Lime Stimulating Masque; sunburned skin benefits from Sour Cherry Whip Moisturizer. The products smell delicious and feel luxurious going on. But the real fun comes when you look in the mirror afterward: Your face is firm and glowing, and feels soft and supple. There is some extracting, but calming creams are used so you can even hit the town that night, sans redness.

Entry fee $18. Average price for additional services $60.

This Korean-run and -patronized spa harks back to the days when spa-ing meant sweating en masse, and no one much fussed about ambience. The entryway is quiet and low-lit?ladies go right and men go left, please?but in the back things cut loose. The sauna and steam rooms are fairly tame, but if the formidable six-jet whirlpool doesn't stun your body into submission, the hot and cold dipping pools will. If you want to fork out for a massage or body scrub (average price $60), there are no-nonsense experts to accommodate you. The locker rooms can be loud. There is refuge, however, for those who prefer to wind down a little more quietly. Beat a hasty retreat to the post-spa area, a darkened room where Barcoloungers abound, and hope that no one's turned on the television?unless you're into Korean soap operas. There's also a sushi bar, where you can score a decent roll, but the hours can be willy-nilly.

text.content: The museum’s artifact-packed permanent displays include items from Native American tribes from across the country, as well as Canada. See baskets, masks, ceremonial dolls, wooden carvings and other historic items that span the centuries; most have been culled from local collector John Mitchell’s personal collection.

address.sort_string: Mitchell Museum of the American Indian

text.content: Sick of hiking to the â€˜burbs to get your fix on this store’s beauty basics? Save your gas money and head downtown. From Dolce & Gabbana perfume to Neutrogena skincare, Ulta makes beauty accessible for any price point. If you can’t find something among the three floors of more than 21,000 beauty products (cosmetics, fragrances, hair care, skincare, bath and body), good luck finding it elsewhere. The shop even offers brands unavailable at other locations such as hair accessories by Lavender Girl, Colette Malouf and France Luxe. The fourth floor contains The Salon at Ulta, led by David Barnett of the John Barrett Salon in Bergdorf Goodman. Stylists, colorists and skincare specialists offer complimentary consultations.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hours), Red to Chicago. Bus: 66

It's easy to get lost in this multi-level spa, but we always head right downstairs to sign in for a super relaxing manicure with paraffin and a scalp and neck massage. (The gift shop is also down there, and we always manage to pick up a scented candle or two.) Upstairs, you'll find services from a nutritionist, plastic surgeon and even a sleep specialistâ€”convenient for those looking for a one-stop spa. Our only complaint? The table was a little wobbly during our massage, but we were so stress-free by that point, that we didn't even mind.
text.author: Kevin Aeh

Under a glass dome and in greenhouse rooms on just over a half acre of land thrive more than 40,000 plants representing around 200 species. Attractions include an extensive fern collection, a room full of dozens of orchid varieties and a 100-year-old, 50-foot rubber tree. Flower shows change with the seasons.

Located in the heart of the city's Ukrainian Village, this museum houses traditional clothing, musical instruments, agricultural tools and folk art from the Eastern European nation. Also on site are a library with more than 16,000 books and periodicals, and a set of archives that document the cultural happenings of Chicago's Ukrainian community.
El: Brown, Red to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 76

A peek at the treatment menu reveals that Shen Shen Health & Harmony is more than just another massage and beauty hotspot, it's a medicinal destination armed with skilled practitioners who want to relieve whatever is ailing youâ€”whether it's back pain, indiegestion, a smoking addiction or a running injury. The signature treatment is a combo of Tui Na (rigorous Chinese massage) and acpuncture, but guasha (skin-scraping), cupping, Shiatsu (Japanese pressure point therapy), Reiki (chakra healing) and the Trager Approach (subtle energetic touch) are also popular options. And don't be surprised if your therapist recommends an herb or supplement to continue the healing process after your treatmentâ€”she'll slowly and thoughtfully discuss how she arrived at her prescription and how it should benefit your body. If you're looking for a natural approach to wellness, this place is for you.
text.author: lplosser

Tucked into the heart of downtown Evanston, Egea Spa is a full-service city spa with all the perks of suburbia. Parking is no problem, appointments are generally easily available (even day of) and friendliness abounds. Nail, facial, massage and body treatments are performed with care and expertise.

text.content: Any time a spa designs an entire line of treatments around wine, you can bet we won't be far behind. The 60-minute Grape Vine Aromatherapy Massage ($75) uses your choice of white zinfandel- or strawberry Champagne-infused products to hydrate, detoxify and soothe the skin. The French Wine Facial ($85) and grape manicure/pedicure ($58) keep the booze flowing...at least on the skin. We kept waiting for a glass of wine, but happily settled for grape-infused lotions and serums instead. Other specialty services include the Caviar Facial ($100), ear candling ($55) and eyelash extensions ($250).

This freak-friendly dance destination in Lakeview built its reputation back in the mid-’80s with a mix of German new-wave music, art installations and even transvestite shows. These days, it’s still quirky but more retro, with Prince-tribute, disco and ’80s nostalgia nights. Goths and gays are extra welcome, but the scene here is made up of almost everyone.

The menu tantilizes the over-40 crowd with treatments like Botox, Restylane and Mesotherapy Cellulite and Fat Reduction (microinjections said to break up fat and increaase tissue metabolism). But even if you're not looking to de-vein your legs or plump your lips, Pure has plenty of services that will be right up your alley, such as massage, an array of facials and acupuncture. We tried their microderm abrasion treatment and felt perfectly relaxed and pampered. And the words that come to mind to describe how our skin looked afterwardsâ€”glowing, tight and fresh-facedâ€”doesn't do justice to the rejunevated reflection we saw in the mirror. The talented, friendly staff wants you to feel utterly beautiful and completely cared forâ€”and they deliver on both counts.
text.author: lplosser

address.name: Ruby Room
address.cross_streets: between Hermitage Ave and Wood St

text.content: It’s a healing sanctuary, a spa, an elixir bar, a yoga studio, a crystal bar, a hair salon, a meditation studio, an educational laboratory, an apothecary and a makeup-to-lifestyle-products retail space all rolled into one 10,000-square-foot space. Ruby Room, located in Wicker Park and easily recognizable by its red double doors, recently reopened in the newly minted category of outside-in rejuvenating venues known as the “spa of the spirit.” Besides its size, the biggest difference between Ruby Room and most other spas is that its treatments skew more to your energetic system with such offerings as intuitive-energy healing, chakra cleansing, crystal-energy healing and astrology. Owner Kate Leydon may have created a spa dynasty, and from the briskness of business here, it looks like she has plenty of followers.

text.content: With waiting lists to get into the Cheesecake Factory longer than an hour on most days, we’re glad that fingers & toesâ€”located just inside the John Hancock buildingâ€”is a mere 10 steps away from the madness. Stop in for a mani($15) or pedi ($30), and you’ll receive quick service, a serene salon with really comfortably pedicure couches and a decent nail jobâ€”although we’d prefer if our nail tech were a little more thorough.

The longstanding modern dance group Chicago Moving Company runs the dance programming in this spacious second-floor studio that overlooks a swimming pool and a playing field. Mornings cater to intermediate and advanced dancers, while after-work and weekend classes offer respite from cubicle confinement.

Just off of one of the busiest intersections in hipland, this multilevel venue has survived a few noise violations to become more relevant than ever. The upstairs is devoted to a live stage (viewable from a third-floor balcony), which features indie, garage, hip-hop and jammy acts nightly (see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop). The downstairs bar serves as a cozy dance den for locals to let loose. The weekly lineup includes hip-hop, reggae and some very fine mod and soul nights.

With rich bamboo flooring, light fixtures from Italy and a hand-painted mural by local artist Heather Gentile inspired by one of Maria Pinto’s subtle lace patterns, the Chicago-based designer’s first store echoes the goal of her clothing: To create a luxurious experience. The eponymous, 2,100-square-foot boutique features Pinto’s full collection of womenswear ($350 and up), which includes jackets made from kangaroo leather, coats, cocktail attire and the evening dresses Michelle Obamaâ€”a longtime Pinto fanâ€”has been photographed wearing.

The vivid colors and exotic look of this cozy establishment have weathered to ridiculous kitsch, but the spirit at the venerable venue is strong. Weekends are jammed with crunkers, sitters and sippers. Tuesdays host the musically adventurous gay-friendly party OUTdanced!; and mid-week, Top 40 hip-hoppers and underground R&B divas sometimes drop in for live sets.

Comfortable, casual and a little quirky, this neighborhood spa is the kind of place where you would feel at ease showing up in old sweats for salt-glow rejuvenation or a sun-glow jolt. The cucumber water is familiar enough, but all the Chiclets you can chew? You don’t get that everywhere. The spa provides robe and slippers as well as primping creams and tonics for your after-treatment use. The friendly staff dotes on men and women equally.

Founded to house the biological and anthropological collections assembled for the World’s Columbian Exposition of 1893, this massive museum of natural history still packs ’em in with more than 30 permanent exhibitions covering more than 300,000 square feet. Inside the permanent displays, you can get glared at by glowering dinos, marvel at ancient artifacts from a royal Egyptian tomb, undergo a lesson in cannibalism in the “Pacific Spirits” gallery or take a stroll through the Halls of Gems and Jade. Buzzworthy permanent exhibitions have made the Field their home in the last few years: “Ancient Americas” explores 30,000 years of history in North, South and Central America, and the glass-fronted “DNA Discovery Center” shows scientists at work tracking animal gene-sequences in order to protect the Earth’s biodiversity.

And they ought toâ€”local designer Chatzka assisted both as an intern in New York. Accessories such as headbands, cuffs and change purses go for less than $50 a pop.

Toujours is French for “everyday or always,” and that’s just what this salon-spa delivers: a cornucopia of beauty and spa services available every day (many spas are closed Sundays and Mondays). This Andersonville spot’s first floor is for hair and nail services and has all the hustle and bustle of a busy salon. But head downstairs to the cavernous spa area and you’ll find tranquility and silence. Four subterranean spa rooms are low-lit and fully equipped for massage, facials, waxing, laser services and the one-of-a-kind Raindrop Technique (a healing massage with essential oils). Shop the high-end selection of skin- and hair-care products (including Phyto and PrivÃ©) on the first floor before you hit the door.)

address.name: Chicago Yoga Center
address.cross_streets: between Nelson St and Wellington Ave

text.content: This studio has been around since 1984, and we can easily see whyâ€”the teachers totally know their stuff. Suddha Weixler, the director, lived in a monastic setting for eight years to learn the classical system. That's hard core. Chicago Yoga Center is on the third floor of a building filled with other artsy studios, and the center consists of one room. That means no one else is practicing at the same time as you, so you can be assured a really peaceful, quiet experience. They offer Astanga, Vinyasa, Yin, open and beginning classes, in addition to a host of ever changing workshops and teacher training sessions.
El: Blue to Washington. Orange, El: Green, El: Brown, El: Purple (rush hour only) to Randolph

This historic architectural treasure morphed from the Reliance Building into the Hotel Burnham. Yet a National Historic Landmark, the hotel isn't stuck in the 19th century. The Kimpton Group has brought its trademark exuberance to the 103 guestrooms and 19 suites, embellished with rich indigo blue and gold fabrics with mischievous cherubs and musical figures. Grab some nosh at Atwood CafÃ© or indulge in free wine, offered every night (5-6pm) in the lobby.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in lobby & via cable in rooms).

Directed by accomplished aerialist Shayna Swanson, this popular spot for off-the-floor dance and graceful circus arts recently moved (June 1) to this spacious new facility. It’s your one-stop shop for training in bungee dancing, body conditioning, trapeze, stilt dancing and burlesque.

Metro is one of the city’s older and more famous clubs. Formerly known as the Cabaret Metro, it hosts a variety of midsize national touring acts of all genres, from rock to hip-hop to electronica. It’s also known for larger showcases of local bands, such as the annual Chicago Rocks fest, where you can catch a slew of the city’s top hip-hop artists all in one night. A number of its shows are all-ages or 18-and-older, so you’ll likely be frequenting it. Downstairs you’ll often find excellent DJs at the adjacent Smart Barâ€”see Clubs listings for more.
El: Pink or Green to Ashland. Bus: 65, 20

The thrifty-and those who don't mind community acupuncture-come flocking to Red Flower for good reason. Erica Blair Reilly charges a sliding scale ($20-$40 depending on your income) for her excellent services. Acupuncture takes place on one of many comfy chairs scattered throughout the beautiful loft, and if you are comfortable talking quietly about your personal problems (anything from digestive to reproductive issues) while strangers sit just a few feet away, then this is the perfect place for you

address.cross_streets: at Lincoln Ave and Roscoe St

text.content: Laura Rose Boyle likes to begin sessions on a floor rug administering Breema bodywork (moves that gently stretch the muscles). This allows her to “listen” to your body and determine while areas need attention. You can move to the massage table, but we suggest remaining on the floor for a fully-clothed Thai massage, during which Boyle melts the tension away using stretching techniques she learned while studying in Thailand.
El: Brown, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy. Bus: 126, 151, 156

The tallest building in the country, this 1973 landmark occupies two city blocks and stretches 1,454 feet high. Skydeck views from the 103rd floor allow you to see as far as 50 miles out. While you’re up there, learn about the city’s landmarks from a multilingual computer program and about its history from wall exhibits. The Skydeck’s newest feature, The Ledge sounds like a horror movie, but there’s a reason for that: Crawl into the Sears Tower’s new glass cube structure, and you’ll be defenselessly suspended 1,353 feet off the ground. If that doesn’t make you want to scream like Sarah Michelle Gellar, nothing will.
Metra: Union Pacific N to Highwood

text.content: Compact but handsomely designed in modern blues and wood, rodan fulfills the fantasy of the hipster who’s moved on from squalid nights sucking PBRs in no-name dives. The menu includes reliably filling Asian and South American dishes and Japanese white ales. DJs spin wildly eclectic sets to their own tastesâ€”anything from Afrobeat and soul to space rock and psychâ€”and the big video screen and weekly live avant-jazz make it a multimedia mecca.

text.content: Tucked into the second floor of an Old Town office building, the small muted green space is low on frills (pedicure stations are office chairs with metal bowls), but high on service. Owner and former flight attendant Megan Parr ensures tools are cleaned religiously, industry trends are followed closely and training is rigorous. Personal attention (color preferences are recorded), details like crystal nail files (said to be less abrasive) and long-lasting polish compensate for subpar dÃ©cor. Basic, spa and sanctuary manicures and pedicures are available, as are gel and acrylic services.

This slick, modern, multilevel Euro-style club in River North opened to much fanfare in 2004 and has kept clubbers busy ever since. On weekends, resident DJs, costumed dancers and powerful sound create a spectacular scene in the multiroom venue. Touring big-name DJs in techno and progressive house usually play Friday nights with residents spinning house and electro on Saturdays. On long holiday weekends, the club squeezes in popular internationally oriented nights.

text.content: Tucked away on the second floor of a quaint West Town building, this full-service spa is instantly inviting with cool aqua-blue walls, deep chocolate brown chairs and a precocious pup named Maxwell who greets each guest with a wagging tail. The extensive menu includes quick beauty fixes like eyelash tinting ($25), lip plumping ($20) and face bronzing ($25) as well as more time (and wallet)-intensive custom massage and facial treatments. The signature 90-minute Top Shelf Facial ($120) features a customized enzyme cocktail and hand, arm, neck, shoulder and back massages. Â

The hotel is a thoroughly high-tech operation, from the ergonomically designed furniture to the 42nd-floor state-of-the-art fitness center offering jaw-dropping views of Lake Michigan. In fact, each of the 632 rooms was designed to provide a lake or river view. Carnivores take comfort in prime beef at Chicago’s version of the Palm.
*High-speed internet ($9.95 wireless & via cable in rooms).

Housed in a former synagogue and theater and set on a quiet residential street, this museum is purportedly the only one in the country devoted to the leather lifestyle. Paintings of men with bulging biceps and perfect “packages” adorn the walls of the worship hall. Downstairs, visitors can thumb through around 10,000 underground sex magazines and peruse exhibits featuring leather whips, a 19th century chastity belt for men and common kitchen tools used for sex play.

Co-owner Quinn Kearney regularly works with the tantric-happy Sting whenever he comes to town, and word has it he's even known to pop in for class. The studio does the occasional workshop, with emphasis on ongoing classes and a focus on vinyasa-flow breathing and alignment.

Tea and frothy coffees are served in the art-filled sunken lobby, while the classy, revamped Aria bar serves sushi with glasses of Evolution, its signature champagne and sake cocktail.

text.content: Everything is pink at the Garden Salonâ€”the walls, the candles, much of the nail polishâ€”even the toilets. Stepping out of the elevator into this second-floor spa is a bit like stepping back in time when salons were called beauty parlors and women chatted for hours under dome-shaped dryers and bad fluorescent lighting. But don’t let appearances fool youâ€”facilities may be a bit dated and personnel may be on the older side, but massage, nail and body treatment services are top notch. Long-term employees knead, file, polish and wax with the confidence earned from years of practice.

address.name: G.R. N'Namdi Gallery
address.cross_streets: between Randolph St and Washington Blvd

text.content: Barneys has transferred its New York City sophistication lock, stock and barrel to Chicago, and packed the attitude for good measure. Professionals and socialites head here (the department store moved to bigger digs across the street from its original outpost in April 2009) for top designer and private label apparel: clothing, jewelery, bags, shoes and accessories.

address.name: Corbett vs. Dempsey
address.cross_streets: between Haddon Ave and Thomas St

text.content: Originally on the fourth floor of the magnificent Wrigleyville building (also home to Metro; see Music venues, Rock, pop & hip-hop), this venerated dance club is now in the basement. A makeover in 2006 slicked up the looks a notch and brought back a vibrant young crowd. But more important, the club boasts a world-class Funktion One sound system, which sounds tremendous on the central dance floor. Cutting-edge DJs from Europe, Detroit and Chicago form the bulk of the weekend bookings with house, techno and electro styles; but local mash-up and indie jocks rule on bargain weekday nights.
El: Red, Green to Garfield. Bus: 6, 55, 59, 170

Frank Lloyd Wright called this Hyde Park home “the cornerstone of modern architecture.” Though it fell into disrepair and was slated for demolition on more than one occasion, it’s now in the midst of a ten-year, $8-million restoration overhaul. One of the last buildings conceived in Wright’s Oak Park studio, it’s considered a prime example of the Prairie-style.

address.cross_streets: between Francisco Ave and Mozart St

text.content: Local eccentric fund-manager and philanthropist Driehaus has opened this museum to publicly display his expansive collection of Louis Comfort Tiffany lamps and accessories, and other late 19th century furnishings. Housed inside the mansion built by 19th-century liquor-magnate Samuel M Nickerson, the immaculately rehabbed “marble palace” is also a shining example of building preservation.
El: Purple to Dempster. Bus: 93, 206 Evanston Circulator

text.content: It wasn’t a love of collecting cool, vintage threads that inspired Lana McAllister to open this shop. Although she’s always been a fan of old-school, quirky clothes, she initially started selling her collections to take her mind off of her love life. “Three years ago I got dumped, and I needed something to do,” McAllister says. She was living in a storefront at North and Ashland Avenues, so on the weekends, she and Michelle DeLeon, her business partner, opened McAllister’s apartment to the public and held low-key yard sales under the name Pistol Bazaar. Three years and two apartments later, the grassroots sales have been such a success that they decided to open a legit boutique in West Town. In addition to eclectic clothes from the 1950s through the 1980s, the shop also stocks records and goods from local artists, including Loaded Blanks greeting cards ($3), Sarah Homans’ jewelry constructed from salvaged metal ($25â€“$50), McAllister’s homemade knitwear and earrings ($15â€“$75) and even a photobooth where shoppers can pose for photos ($3). Who says a little retail therapy can’t cure a broken heart?

You won’t find day-spa luxuries such as gourmet nibbles and gratis wine. But what you will get makes up for the lack of frills: Thorough facials, medical-grade chemical peels and surprisingly gentle microdermabrasion provide all of the essentials needed for beautiful skin. The medical spa focuses on result-driven treatments such as photorejuvenation, a noninvasive light therapy that improves skin tone and texture ($499 and up). And while you could opt for waxing services, don’t be surprised if you’re tempted to splurge on laser hair removal. Unlike other laser treatments, Avanti’s machine zaps the fuzz completely, without pain. It’s enough to brighten your mood along with your complexion.

This 11,000-square-foot retreat has “spa day” written all over it. Drop in for a yoga class and you’ll want to linger in the eco-friendly retail area, dine at the cafÃ© and treat yourself to Vosges elixirs and truffles. Better yet, lose yourself in organic-focused treatments like the Singing Bowl ($140) or Organic Stone and Crystal ($160) facials. We hauled our stressed-out selves to Glenview and said we wanted to leave “utterly relaxed.” Our facial technician took the challenge so seriously, we literally had to check to be sure she hadn’t used extra fingers to achieve the desire effect. Ladies can finish with a complementary water ritual, featuring a monsoon shower and signature scrub, aromatherapy steam and sauna and a few moments of quiet in a private room with just you, a cozy chair and a bubbling fountain. Mission accomplished.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156
El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 50 Ashland, 22

For most folks, getting a spa treatment is a special occasionâ€”a once in a blue moon treat. Continuum Studio owners Johnnie Grozenski and Paul Hasenwinkel aim to take that splurge-feeling out of their Andersonville spa and teach clients that frequent services are like therapy for the bodyâ€”essential and carthartic. That's not to say you won't luxuriate in your surroundings. You will. The rooms are dim and warm and the selection of hand-picked, decadent products (like the French skincare line Creme Pou Les Mains), near the front desk is staggering. As you're being blissfully rubbed, scrubbed or steamed during one of a plethora of reasonably-priced massages and skin care services on offer, don't be surprised if you develop a healthy addiction for this friendly spot.
text.author: lplosser

address.street: 835 N Michigan, 3rd floor of the Water Tower

text.content: Everything reminds us of a doctor's office at Georgette Klinger, from the tubes of products in the waiting room down to the white uniforms the aestheticians wear while they're performing the services in the silent, bare treatment areas. But this was one “doctor's office” we wouldn't mind returning to again and again. While they offer a range of services, they're best known for their facials, which are extraordinary. They start with an in-depth conversation about your skin before the customized facial tackles every area on your face, neck, upper back, hands and feet using luxury SkinCeutical lotions, toners and masks. We walked in with a face filled with blemishes, and we left with soft, clear skin. We just wish they wouldn't have pressured us to buy their (excellent) products.

address.cross_streets: between Washington Blvd and Randolph St

text.content: This spacious, unpretentious Ukrainian Village nightspot has gradually upgraded sound and stage features, enabling it to turn from rock bar to DJ den in a flash. The photography-themed decor extends to displays of local photographers’ prints. DJ nights for reggae, hip-hop and house predominate, but rock, indie and electro nights are frequent. Somehow, it’s never gotten overly hip, which might be because it needs a headcount of 100 before it starts to get cozy.

Our favorite part of spa-ing at the Peninsula Hotel Spa is the time we spend chilling in the newly remodeled lounge area. Single-person beds with fluffy comforters nestle in private, draped enclaves. You can spend hours reading or napping, completely undisturbedâ€”except for someone refilling your tall glass of fruit-infused water or mug of tea. Nearby ther's a flickering fireplace. The spa menu is pricey (manicures start at $35), but the top-notch products (like June Jacobs) make a body treatment worth the splurge.

address.street: 1827 S Indiana Ave (tours meet at Glessner House)

text.content: Before the likes of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe or even Louis Sullivan started putting Chicago on the architectural map, this 1836 Greek Revivalâ€“style home, graced with a four-column portico, symbolized the first national architectural style. It also lays claim to being the city’s oldest house.

prices.ticket_reference: Joint tour of Clarke and Glessner Houses: $15, students and seniors $12, kids ages 5â€“12 $8 and kids under 5 free.

text.content: Like Dorothy’s ruby slippers, Equilibrium, a wellness center on Printers Row dedicated to energy healing, wants to bring you back to a safe, comfy and happy emotional place. Longtime healer Bernadette Doran has created a sanctuary where she leads clients through an impressive array of traditional energy-healing techniques, such as reiki, and color therapy. And she’s brought in healers to provide unique experiences like colorpuncture (acupuncture with focused colored light instead of needles), aura-soma (color and light therapy) and holographic memory resolution (a combination of guided visualization and energy work used to heal emotional trauma). Doran also holds workshops and lectures at least once a week. Whether you’re a believer, a skeptic or just curious about this sort of stuff, Doran’s warm personality will make you feel right at home.

In 2008, taking over the former Rive Gauche space, another nightlife contender entered the fray. The usual combination of go-go dancers, bottle service booths and energetic house and electro remixes might not set this place apart. the faux display windows are occupied by sloppily posed mannequins which don't do much for the glamour vibe. On the other hand, the open floor plan is ace for people watching and seeing and being seen. The young folks, particularly suburban based adventurers, love it.

text.content: The folks at the newly remodeled downstairs spa encourage guests to come early so they can enjoy a relaxing aromatherapyfoot bath in the dimly lit lounge. While you soak your peds in a warm, soothing blen of rose, vanilla and lavender oils, a therapist will wrap a heated, herb-scented pillow around your neck and massage your feet and calves with finely ground walnut shells, kelp, aloe, lavender and herbal extracts. The pretreatment ritual is so relaxing, it's almost a buzzkill to have to get up for your scheduled service. Almost.

When this institution opened in 1961, African-American history was suffering serious neglect at the hands of the city’sâ€”and for that matter the nation’sâ€”cultural institutions. The Hyde Park cultural hub is now one of the oldest and most respected African-Americanâ€“focused museums in the country. On display are documents and artifacts from the lives of overlooked or unjustly marginalized movers and shakers, plus a collection of vibrant African-American art.

The original cro in the dance-club franchise (there are now crobar outposts in Miami, New York and South America) was remodeled a few years ago with a South Beachâ€“meetsâ€“industrial materials look. These days, the club hosts everything from a midweek Latin night to visits from big-name techno, house and trance DJs. But a typical weekend night features residents hammering with au courant dance tracks while girls on platforms demonstrate the finer points of deca dancing.

Soar to this eighth floor spa in a cloud-lined elevator and melt into 9,000 square feet of premium pampering space. This New York import features 16 treatment rooms, four movie-while-you-manicure stations with personal DVD players and a full slate of massage, nail and body treatments. Try the signature triple layer oxygen facial ($150), said to clean, calm, hydrate and illuminate. Warning: Prices are as lofty as the lake views.

This Wicker Park spot, which once housed BigWig, may have changed names more than any other venue in town, but it’s become an unlikely hipster hangout in 2008 with its Monday night Rehab party. It sports two levels, a back room, booths in front and a dancefloor that gets cozy real quick, plus a late-night license.
El: Red line to Grand. Bus: 29, 36

To get to the spa here, you have to walk past the busy salon area downstairs, to the serene floor they reserved for spa pampering. While not too plush, the brown tones throughout the spa give it a relaxed, calming feel â€“ even though the spa space isn't huge. They use all Aveda products, and we sampled their offerings though a 1 Â½ hour Ultimate Rejuvenating Body Treatment ($120), which includes a body wrap, a scalp massage and a facial. Heavenlyâ€”although we wouldn't recommend the manicures and pedicures, which take place in the hallway between the stairs and the spa waiting room.

text.content: Neither the library’s classic architecture nor its patrician setting betray its mission to bring high-brow culture to the plebs. All exhibitions, which generally revolve around a book or lit theme, are free. And anyone can browse the 2-million volume collection that specializes in Chicago history, genealogy, cartography and printing. All you need is a reading card, which will require a photo ID, proof of address and a reason for wanting to search a specific collection.

text.content: It's a oneâ€“woman, oneâ€“room show at this skincare spot. Owner and aesthetician Liz Quesnelle opened up shop in 2003 after learning the ropes at the Aveda Institute and assisting an M.D. at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where she specialized in skin disorders and corrective cosmetics. Thanks to her rigorous training and hospital experience, Quesnelle has an honest, optimistic, yet scientific approach to skincare (she does makeup application and lessons, too). And as a rule, she doesn't sell products (“you can get great stuff for a lot less at any drugstore”) and she follows up after sessions with each client via email. It's a small operation but the facials are fantasticâ€“and we felt like we were in the hands of a pro with the bubbly, but not overly chatty, Quenelle.

text.content: During the heyday of frilly Victorian architectural styles, Wright designed and lived in this structure that still looks modern by today's standards. He continuously changed its interior to test his theories, and from that work came his legendary Prairie-style, characterized by nature-inspired elements, horizontal lines and low-pitched roofs.

A restaurant and jazz venue, Green Dolphin turns into a dance club several nights a week with salsa one night and house another. The legendary and long-running Boom Boom Room house night on Mondays draws a diverse clientele for polysexual dancing in several rooms that continues into the wee hours.

text.content: Waxing specialist Sisters is known for being one of the first spas in the country to take it all off down there. Founders Jeannette Abou-Mourad and Elaine Youhanna have been giving the “honeymoon” wax since they were teenagers in Lebanon (Jeannette was quick to remind us that the “Brazilian” is named after the bikini-style, not to be confused with waxings' origins, which are Middle Eastern). All those years have paid off: The ladies have honed frill-free waxing down to an art form and Chicago's who's-who make monthly pilgrimages to the Water Tower Place location for speedy, clean, impeccable and less painful waxing experience.

A downtown destination for the past 15 years, this superclub is housed in a historic church and seemingly has a room for everything: There’s a weekly cabaret show, live flamenco music, Latin dance lessons and even a paranormal interactive-theater event. With all the cross-promotion going on, it draws a crowd of enthusiastic out-of-towners and club novices who would settle for a mediocre experience.

Tucked behind the loud, buzzing hair stations in this spa/salon's front area, you'll find a peaceful, contemporary sanctuary that puts you right at ease. Every treatment under the sun is available in the stone and steel outfitted-spaceâ€”from manicures to massages to waxing to body glows. But folks in-the-know come for the expert facials. We love the new Beyond Botox service ($130), which totally elimated our forehead wrinkles and blemishes and left us with a glow that lasted for days. Two complimentary rain showers are available for all guests, so plan ahead and schedule some time in one before or after your treatment.
text.author: lplosser

The public spaces are decked out with Italian marble, glittering crystal and exquisite woodwork; rooms and suites come with classy furnishings, high-end toiletries and twice-daily maid service. Seasons, a clubby cigar bar and lounge features fireplace, waterfall and Magnificent Mile views.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in public spaces; free wireless & via cable in rooms).

This massage salon in Streeterville offers a yearlong membership where customers can sign up for monthly 50-minute massages for just $59. (The same service costs nonmembers $98.) If you find yourself too busy during certain times of the year, the rub-down carries over to the next month; and at the other end of the spectrum, those with extra time on their hands can purchase additional massages for only $49. The chain has more than 400 locations across the country, so you can even relieve stress while road tripping.

text.content: The calendar is anything-goes at this straightforward neighborhood lounge. It’s got a late-night license and has room for live rockabilly music, hip-hop and juke DJs on the weekends, and periodic house and techno marathons. The cover is usually low.
El: Brown to Irving Park. Bus: 11, 50, 80, 78

The organic sister club to Funky Buddha (see below) is a newcomer with a healthy, earth-friendly agenda and an interior molded from Central American mud. The hippy-green aspect extends to alcohol-free stimulant drinks, partially off-the-grid power, organic spirits and ice cubes made from spring water. Luckily, the DJs are up to par, delivering hip-hop and soulful dance with an international bent.

This retreat on the ever-busy Canal Street has always been our fall-back when we need a Loop fix. But its services (an array of massages, body wraps, facials and even acupuncture) have become hit-or-miss. When we sampled the spa’s Organic Blueberry-Guava Detox Wrap ($110 for 45 minutes)â€“our therapist left us all wrapped up like a mummy and alone in the room for 10 minutes. Moneywise, that equates to roughly $24.40 worth of alone time. That said, other times we’ve visited the spa have left us impressed with its competent massages and luxury facials. Our suggestion: Skip the complicated stuff and stick to the basics here. You can always eat the blueberries and guava at home, or spread them on your body yourself if you’re so inclined.

text.content: This Wicker Park spot is the JetBlue of bodywork. It’s the same pricing structure used by airlines: Walk-ins willing to pay a premium for convenience subsidize those who plan ahead. Owner Mike Flatley is on a mission to bring massage, essential oil therapy, reiki and acupuncture to the masses by using some good old-fashioned business sense. The basic rate for a walk-in who wants a 50-minute session is a respectable $75; call at least one hour ahead and you’ll pay only $50, or book one or more days in advance and pay just $45. For those looking to upgrade, a tandem massageâ€”four hands working at once for 50 minutesâ€”is a bargain at $85 (about half of what you’d pay elsewhere), while the 50-minute, nine-oil Raindrop Therapy is only $65. (You can add a boost of essential oils to any treatment for an additional $1â€“$15.) Customers who buy in bulk get the best deal of all: a prepaid ten-pack of 50-minute massages for a very Zen $360.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Diversey. Bus: 9, 11, 76
El: Green, Pink to Clinton. Bus: 8, 56, 65

This raucous new rocker bar has loads going for it: It’s in a space with its own working-class history (as a hangout for railway workers), stays open very late, and the DJs play almost exclusively rock, usually of the psych, indie and garage varieties.

address.cross_streets: between Michigan Ave and Rush St

text.content: Ladies who lunch get their eyebrows in order at Channing?s Day Spa, where owner Cheryl Renella plucks perfect arches and tames bushy brows. The cozy Gold Coast spa sits snugly above Oak Street, welcoming the tired and the hungry, but perhaps not the poor. Brow shaping, the spa?s signature service, runs $100 for the first visit and $55 thereafter. Other services include Swedish and hot rock massage, aromatherapy and clarifying facials, a variety of body wraps, manicures and pedicures.

We’ll speak for the many “mature” residents of the tony Gold Coast neighborhood by saying Christopher Charles has certainly done its demographic homework. The posh spa, featuring stunning views of Michigan Avenue and the lake from its comfy mani/pedi room, offers antiaging skin care via an extensive menu of facials, from preventative care (the Vita-C Anti-Aging, $145, promotes collagen synthesis) to corrective (the Lighten and Resurface, $165, evens out sun-damage spots) and clinical (an on-staff M.D. gives Botox injections). But don’t miss the fantastic body treatments: The Scentao massage ($150) is 90 minutes of heaven, incorporating hot stones and acupressure. You’ll leave the spa feeling as giddy as a little kid.

text.content: If we ever create our own spa, we want it to look exactly like Mojo'sâ€”pink everywhere, princess-worthy manicure chairs and natural products galore. The owner, Amanda, used to be a professional chef, but she turned her creative juices to skincare, and we are thrilled with the result. She makes all the products in her studio, which is six blocks away, and they smell and feel scrumptious. If you could tear yourself away from the retail at the front of the spa, head back for a super-pampered mani and pedi, where nail techs will use all of Amanda's lotions and scrubs on your hands and feet. Our hands smelled so good afterwards, that the person sitting next to us at a concert later in the evening commented on our scent. Come on Sundays for Amanda's homemade brunch, which is complimentary with any service.

The newest Michael Anthony outpost is luxuriously calm despite its strip-mall location. Downstairs from the hair salon is the tranquil spa (offering massages, facials, hand/foot care), where our bod was was treated to a Body Polish, leaving us buffed and baby-smooth, before the Hot Stone Massage got us dozing. (True, our room was somewhat frigid and the masseuse pulled our hair but we’ll chalk that up to newness.) Best of all was the shower-room, complete with jetstreams and fragrant Aveda products galore.

This stunning Beaux Arts building, which started out as a private men’s club in 1929, has been transformed into one of Starwood’s sleek W Hotels. The 369 rooms come with pillow-top mattresses and the option of an in-room shiatsu massage. You can request just about anything (legal) you desire from W’s signature Whatever/Whenever service, which once reportedly hired a helicopter to fetch a guest’s wedding cake.
High-speed internet (free wireless in lobby; $14.95 via cable in rooms).

Anchoring the Prairie Avenue Historic District, this enduring structure is the only Henry Hobson Richardson home left in the city. Romanesque, fortresslike and defined by medieval architecture typified by rough-hewn stone and arched entryways, it had a notable influence on the early careers of Frank Lloyd Wright and Louis Sullivan.

prices.ticket_reference: Joint tour of Clarke and Glessner Houses: $15, students and seniors $12, kids ages 5â€“12 $8 and kids under 5 free.

text.content: Explore this country from prehistory to the present, or view temporary exhibits by Lithuanian-American artists. Researchers and genealogists are welcome to thumb through several archives. Kids can try out armor and weaponry inside a mock castle.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Wellington or Belmont; Red to Belmont. Bus: 8

First the (very) good news. The treatments here rank with the best in the city. Aestheticians have medical training so you're in able, confident hands whether you're getting a classic facial, microderm abrasion or a chemical peel. Our aesthetician listened closely to our skin concerns, then fixed up with yummy-smelling, 100% organic Ilika products (bonus points: she didn't pressure us to purchase anything). Massage and acupuncture are also on the menu, and are often part of the medical treatment plan given by one of the center's doctors. Which leads us to the (slightly) bad news. The spa is in a medical building, so you don't exactly get the cushy, lounge-in-slippers preface to your service like you would at a traditional spa. No matter, when you walk out the door totally thrilled with your glowing complexion, you couldn't care less what that door actually looked like.

price.price_type: $60 for laser hair removal, $145 for microdermabrasion facial.

text.content: This museum’s interactive displays keep kids occupied with dinosaurs, a hands-on laboratory, nature exhibits and more. Other exhibits teach lessons on the water cycle, life under the sea and the great outdoors.

price_id.general_remark: Thursdays free 5â€“8pm; free for youth 15 and under the first Monday of each month.

Massages are the specialty here, and the spa offers every typeâ€”from the classic Swedish to the ashiatsu (therapist uses feet to massage you) and the oncology (a blend of Eastern and Western treatments to get you rested). While the massages are excellent, the best part of the spa is outside the treatment rooms, where you can choose between three complimentary showers: steam, rain (heavy overhead water flow) and European style (multiple jets). Before your appointment, the receptionist will ask if you’d like a shower. Your answer should be yes. And if you have the foresight to do it, we recommend you call ahead to schedule the shower because our favoriteâ€”the rainshowerâ€”is sometimes overbooked.

Upon stepping into the adorably red, black and grey-outfitted Trim, it's clear from the numerous hair-removal tools, waxing stations and eager aestheticians that the waxing salon takes an obsessive approach to hair removalâ€”in a good way. Trim carries vitamin-enriched waxes for different skin types and sensitivity levels, and sells products to help keep skin soft and smooth afterward (like bikini brushes and exfoliants). The therapists are quick, friendly and adept with wax. It'll only take a few minutes to transform unkempt brows into pretty curves. Brazalians are a treatment option, but daring types may opt for something bolderâ€”anal brightening comes to mind (yes, you read that right)? The menu has dozens of waxing, threading, tweezing and tinting options, so you can groom yourself from head to, er, bum.

address.cross_streets: between Roscoe St and Newport Ave

text.content: El: Red, Brown to Addison. Bus: 9, 152

When proprietress Janet Doherty left her native Ireland eight years ago, she shed her Gaelic name, Sinead, and took Janet, the Yankee translation. Doherty stuck to her roots when she christened her new Lakeview spa, but the Celtic flavor is most evident in her lilting brogue, which adds an extra kick of comfort to her pampering arsenal. The spa is on the first floor of a two-flat and is warm and welcoming, like a friend's uncluttered living room, but not overly hedonistic. Besides facials and body treatments (average $80), the spa offers spot services to renew eyes and hydrate lips.

A standing testament to the work of humanitarian Jane Addams, this museum is housed in the home she opened in 1889 to serve people in need, including a young Benny Goodman who learned to play clarinet there. The text-intensive displays supplement paintings that hung at the settlement, pottery and tableware created through her community art program, her desk and, next door, the dining hall where she and residents shared meals.

prices.ticket_reference: Reservations required for tours and groups.

text.content:
This 144-room boutique hotel on Jewelers Row is an architectural gem. The late 19th-century Arts and Crafts style is evident outside and in, with wrought-iron pieces adding accents to the comfortable (if slightly dated) decorations in each room. Guests can get their sweet fix during the complimentary dessert hour.
*High-speed internet (free wireless in lobby & via cable in rooms).

Working with just 900 square feet, the two women behind this Rogers Park spa have managed to create a warm, relaxing space that doesn?t skimp on luxurious touches. Slip off your shoes in the plant-filled, sun-splashed waiting area, head to one of three dimly lit treatment rooms, climb onto the heated massage table and snuggle up against butter-soft flannel sheets. Both Liz Ellis and Suzen Cook are trained doulas (midwives), and offer massage from pregnancy to deep tissue. Cook, who worked at Santa Fe?s Ten Thousand Waves, also specializes in body treatments such as herbal wraps, salt or sugar glows, and a fantastic head and neck treatment: Warm oil is massaged into your hair and scalp, and refreshingly cool marble stones are used to work the oil into your face. Also soothing is the hot stone massage, in which Cook kneads heated basalt stones into tight muscles, then places them on your chakras.

This Edgewater spa is mostly dedicated to spot- and hard-to-find massages focusing on the head, face and neck. The resident therapist practices a West Coast technique, beginning on your belly and massaging neck and appendages before turning you over to focus on face, feet, torso and, finally, back. It’s a nice change of pace. Nicer still is the bowl of eucalyptus water strategically placed on the floor so you can inhale the sinus-opening vapors. During the evening, the place is transformed into a studio for belly dancing, group meditations and yoga classes. Don’t leave without buying Cherie Bianco’s homemade all-natural soaps, scrubs and creams.
El: Red to Harrison; Blue to LaSalle. Bus: 29, 36, 62

Visiting FLOR's first retail space is like walking into its popular website. Graphics on the wall near the front door explain the modular tile concept (20-inch recycled squaresâ€”starting at $7â€”allow you to design area rugs, runners, or wall-to-wall carpeting), and the rest of the store brims with more than 400 carpet samples and swatches, along with plenty of inspiration to get you started.
Take a self-guided walking tour through the city’s first arboretum, a 30-acre site that opened in 2004 with more than 50 tree varieties from Black Maple to Red Maple.

Though it’s staffed by world-class researchers at the forefront of their field, the museum’s real draw will always be the virtual-reality trips through time and space in the StarRider and Sky Theaters. Themes usually center around the known and unknown universe and how humans have engaged with it throughout history.

Mind, body, spirit takes on new meaning at Tsubo, where you can sweat off lunch in a personal training session, optimize skin in a custom-blended facial and minimize any remaining stress in a balancing Reiki massageâ€”all without leaving the building. Housed in a 4,000-square-foot converted loft in a dusty industrial corridor, Tsubo blends the skills of co-owners Trisha Kaufman, a personal trainer and hairstylist, and Jay Holtman, a massage therapist, to give customers a complete wellness experience. Free weights, salon chairs and massage tables co-mingle amongst hardwood floors, sweeping loft windows and Asian-inspired dÃ©cor. Don’t be intimidated by the building’s near-deserted appearanceâ€”parking is free and plentiful and the walk up the creaky flight of stairs is worth it.

text.content: At the Detox Flow: Purification of Body, Mind & Spirit workshops at Moksha Riverwest, you’ll examine everything you take into your body. The four days of classes will include sun salutations, detox standing sequences, breathing exercises, meditation, dietary counseling and more. Don’t you feel healthier just thinking about it?

Japanese pictures, prints and decorations are plastered on the walls, stemming from the owner's Japanese heritage (he moved to Chicago 20 years ago from Tokyo), making the otherwise barebone salon and spa a little more zen. We wish, however, that the owner would add some Japanese treatments instead of sticking to the basicsâ€”massage, manicure, pedicure and facial (although he promises to start using some Japanese products in the future). The massage we received was decent, although we hope the squeaky wood floors will be oiled soon, to up the relaxation factor.
El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 8, 77, 152

The emphasis is on wide-open space at this after-work lounge that turns clubby later. An interesting LED lighting fixture captures the theme, while some of Chicago’s harder-hustling disco and electro DJs man the booth.

address.cross_streets: between Winona St and Foster Ave

text.content: This Andersonville spa serves the city’s dandies and dudes with the bodywork, skin care and grooming services that they and their admirers increasingly demand. The interior is handsomeâ€” the locker and shower room is done with subway tiles and neutral tones and all aroundâ€”soothing, well-appointed and notably clean. We don’t need ESPN Classic 24/7â€”but there is a 50-inch screen in the grooming club room just in case. They offer everything the most metrosexual man could ever wantâ€”pedis, facials and various types of massage (our favorite is the Ashiatsu Deep Tissue massageâ€”the therapist literally steps on top of you for this one).It also offers several comprehensive total body packages ($200 and up) and Date Night options ($160-$230 per couple). It’s been a winner with both gays and straights and we wouldn’t be surprised to see another location pop up.

text.content: This Pilates studio’s teaching style is true-blue to Joseph H. Pilate’s original exercise. Two large roomsâ€”one for mat exercises, the other for apparatus workâ€”are outfitted with everything needed to develop postural awareness, maximize strength and flexibility, and improve core muscle powerâ€”all in a nonimpact way. Group and individual classes are available at beginner and intermediate levels. A group class is $15, and the studio offers package deals for private sessions as well as reduced rates for training with an apprentice.
Metra: Union Pacific W to Elmhurst

You can get everything from holistic body wraps to haircuts to eyelash extensions here, but our favorite is the incredibly detail-oriented spa pedicure ($46). It’s done in a semiprivate room, which would be perfect for spa days, as it holds three people. The nail technician buffs, massages and polishes your feet and toes for an hour before declaring them stiletto-ready. Just as much attention is paid to the facials, which are usually done by Daniela herself. The one thing the spa doesn’t do is massage, but its menu appears to expand every time we walk in, so maybe we’ll see it soon.
El: Blue, Red to Monroe; Pink, Orange, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Quincy.

This former meatpacking plant is now a tony lounge filled with designer midcentury furniture. Lately, it’s been booking Chicago house and Euro expat nights with a bondage bash thrown-in for variety’s sake.

address.name: The Anti-Cruelty Society Education and Training Center
address.cross_streets: between Wells St and LaSalle Blvd

text.content: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Merchandise Mart. Bus: 22, 65, 156

If you’ve ever vacationed in Ibiza, Spain, and noticed the green heart stickers all over the island, you’ll encounter a case of dÃ©jÃ vu. The stickers are sold in the Ã¼berâ€“eco-friendly GreenHeart Shop. The group behind this River North store is the Center for Cultural Interchange, a nonprofit that offers environmental volunteer and education programs throughout the world. In addition to stocking the typical gifts and home accessories that are safe for the environment (you know, made from bamboo or other sustainable materials), the shop also sells handmade and fairly traded items by artists from all over the globe. There’s women’s jewelry ($10â€“$50) from India, Indonesia and Nepal; ceramic mugs, bowls and umbrella stands from Vietnam ($9â€“$70); and exclusive green heart-shaped bath soaps produced locally ($3). Now, the next time you’re in Ibiza, you can just go for the partying and leave your shopping at home.

text.content: El: Red, orange to Roosevelt. Bus: 1, X3, 4

If you’re not relaxed by the muted orange and brown wall tones, by the candles or by the dim lighting throughout the spa, you must be seriously stressed out. But worry notâ€”the minute you step into Mi Spa Chicago, which is perched on the second floor of a lofted South Loop buildingâ€”your body will start to calm down. Flower petals cover every massage and facial bed, and the pedicures are done in a secluded but beautiful peaceful room. Our hot stone massage ($100) whisked away every ounce of soreness in our tired body, and their make-up applications are so fabulous that even Gov. Rod Blagojevich has gotten his face beautified there (and they’ve got the pics to prove it).
El: Red, Brown to Fullerton. Bus: 11, 74.

This 24.5-acre park features Frank Gehry's Pritzker Pavilion and serpentine bridge; sculptor Anish Kapoor's 110-ton Cloud Gate (a.k.a. “The Bean”); and Jaume Plensa's Crown Fountain, with its ever-changing array of locals' faces spewing water very five minutes in the summer months.
El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Fullerton. Bus: 8, 11, 74

address.name: Lincoln Park Zoo
address.cross_streets: between Lake Shore Dr and Fullerton Pkwy

text.content: See some 1,200 animals, from apes to zebras, at the oldest and one of only a few free zoos left in the country. It is small, only 35 acres, but big attractions like the Kovler Lion House and the Regenstein Center for African Apes pack a big punch.

opening_hours.general_remark: Summer weekends and holidays, grounds close at 7 PM. Late fall - winter, grounds close at 5 PM.

address.street: Charles Gates Dawes House, 225 Greenwood St

text.content: One of Chicagoland’s best-known Polish community hot spots features more rock bands (sometimes visiting from the continent) than DJs, but European techno and even industrial-focused blowouts make an appearance from time to time.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 22, 66

This tiny storefront Pilates studio specializes in private group reformer classes, which are taught by dedicated and informed instructors. They quickly assess your body, determining the pilates routine that works best before getting started with your workout. Our teacher told us that the arch of our feet was formed by our running habit, and our hunched back resulted from staring at a computer all day. Then, she got to work fixing our disheveled body. They offer discounts for private group reformer session with a few friends, and they also have mat classes.
El: Red to Harrison; Orange, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library. 1, 3, X3, 4, X4, 6, 7, 10, 14, 26, 28, 126, 144, 145, 146, 147
El: Brown, Green, Pink, Orange, Purple (rush hrs), Blue to Clark. Bus: 134, 135, 136, 156

From the Tootsie Roll candies at the front desk to the zebra-print robes in the suites, the Allegro boasts a whimsical sense of style. There’s a showbiz theme to the Kimpton Group’s late-’90s transformation: rooms are decorated in vibrant colors, and theatrically themed suites include one decorated like the set of The Lion King. As at other Kimpton hotels, guests enjoy a daily wine hour in the lobby (5-6pm) and an in-room yoga channel.
*High-speed internet (free wireless & via cable in rooms).

address.street: Fine Arts Building, 410 S Michigan Ave, room 1036
address.cross_streets: between Van Buren St and Congress Pkwy

text.content: El: Red to Harrison; Orange, Brown, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to Library. Bus: 3, 4, 14, 22, 29, 36, 62, 147.

Get ready for a dose of decorating delight. Inside this vintage building are unique furniture and accessories worthy of inspiring an entire room: Driftwood sculptures ($135-$1,500), silver plated pitchers and trays with horn handles ($100-$750), zebra rugs ($800) and even cocktail tables mounted on tree trunks ($750-$1200). The garden section carries fresh plants and flowers year-round, plus beautiful pots and planters.

Located just a block away from the Blue line Austin stop, this adorable one-room yoga studio is certainly no trek at all. It's just 20 minutes away from the Loop, but since you're out of the city, you may find it much easier to unwind (especially because there are no mirrors inside, so you can concentrate on your practice rather than your body image flaws). The studio moonlights occasionally as an art gallery, and the cheerful paintings hanging on the exposed brick walls should put you in a good mood. If the scenery doesn't do it for you, simply relax in the very able hands of the instructors, who wander around the room to adjust you and put you in the right position for each pose.

address.name: Congress Theater

text.content: This Gold Coast mind-body spa breaks new ground in luxury. The spin is spa treatments and fitness classes that focus on healing. The atmosphere is part ultramodern and part exotic and the treatments are also a delightful melding of disciplines. You'll find a range of massages (including Thai, four-handed, acupuncture and energetic therapy, which incorporates guided meditation). By far the most wondrous is body enlightening, which is full-body contact with your therapist, who gently and expertly stretches, balances and aligns you from the outside in. The menu extends to nails, facials and waxing, but the spa's crowning glory is the Core Fusion class. It's the signature workout and combines a slew of disciplines that promise to rejuvenate and transform.

address.name: Kaya Day Spa
address.cross_streets: between Randolph St and Washington Blvd

text.content: Climb the wooden stairs to this sprawling West Loop spa and enter a serene loft space boasting high ceilings, exposed brick and a gurgling waterfall. Turn to your left and there's a nail salon; go right, past the “quiet room,” and you're on your way to the cushy changing room, where you're outfitted with a luscious robe (on sale in the front) and therapeutic sandals. Pampering options range from green tea facials to an “East Meets West” body wrap designed to make skin younger, tighter and fresher. Hydrotherapy and massage offerings are also on the menu, but the best part may be the first-floor parking lots sure to guarantee door-to-door serenity.
El: Red to Chicago. Bus: 151, 156, 146 Walton

While the Michigan Avenue address suggests sky-high prices, the small, beige changing areas are no-nonsense and not especially ritzy, highlighting that service is top priority. Unfortunately, we've experienced a few snafus with the spa's black hole of an appointment database. However, once you get into your treatment room, the results are impressive: Try the transformative Classic Facial ($90), which was truly transformativeâ€”our face went from blotchy and flakey to smooth and glowy. Plus, if your aesthetician isn't too busy, she might throw in gratis brow shaping. The salon is equipped with plenty of hair trimming and color stations, while manicure and pedicure chairs are tucked in a separate area.

address.name: Northeastern Illinois University Auditorium

El: Brown, Red, Purple (rush hrs) to Belmont. Bus: 9, 11, 77

“Inhale world, exhale peace.” This has been the school's mantra since 1972, when Korean founder Grand Master MyungSu Y.S. Kim first came up with his plan to promote world peace through meditation. The school remains active in advancing worldwide peace through large-scale initiatives, and the Lincoln Avenue location, a rambling space that has windows, remains a guiding force for an expanding community of peaceniks. Classes range from yoga to martial arts for women, peace breathing to meditation.

The treatment rooms have names like, “Relax me,” “Nurture me” and “Revitalize me.” But the truth is, they ought to go ahead and put a sign on the front door that says, “Spoil me” at this Lincoln Park spa. That's how you feel from the moment a cheerful host and the powerful scent of flickering aromatherapy candles welcomes you into the clean, modern space decked out in warm blue and brown tones and dark wood. Try the signature treatment, a hydrotherapy bath, before a service from the full menu of massages, facials, manicures, waxing and salt scrubs. A tub imported from Australia and outfitted with 77 ahh-inducing jet streams melts the stress out of every muscle in your body ($50 for 30 minutes). Whenâ€”sighâ€”it's time to leave, don't be surprised if you feel like you're floating out the door.
text.author: lplosser

address.name: Honey Child
address.cross_streets: between Superior St and Chicago Ave

text.content: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs), Red to Chicago. Bus: 22, 29, 36, 66

Honey Child has a primo reputation for sweetening your experience by taking its full-service spa services up a pampering notch or two. The menu includes traditional nail, massage and facial servicesâ€”all sure to please. Daredevils can roll the die with one of several exotic waxes, including honeymooner favorite “Hidden Treasures.” It's a full pubic wax artfully adorned with rhinestones or crystals in the shape of your choosing. How do the crystals stick? Trade secretâ€”you'll have to ask.

This Japanese-inspired spa is for women, run by women. Take off your shoes at the door and wind your way around riceâ€“paper screens leading to spa bath facilities. Submit to an herbal wrap, which begins with a dry sauna, eucalyptus steam and Jacuzzi, or try head-to-toe tranquility in the massage therapy room (massage and wraps average $80). Swathed in a kimono, you can put up your feet and sip tea undisturbed (for up to three hours) in the relaxation room. It gets busy, so call ahead on weekends.

address.name: Andy's
address.cross_streets: between State St and Wabash Ave

text.content: El: Red to Bryn Mawr. Bus: 36, 84, 136, 147, 151

Green is the color of choice at Salon Echo, where the emphasis is on environmentally-friendly indulgence. Eighty percent of the pastel-colored salon is made of recyclable materials and all services excluding hair coloring exclusively use botanical products. Fresh flowers, a welcoming staff and a tempting menu of nail, massage and facial services make guilt-free indulgence as easy as dropping a can in the recycling bin.

The studio gets its name from its sunny loft space in the heart of Rogers Park and its emphasis on personalized care. Bodywork like therapeutic massage forms the basis of services, with a particular focus on catering to the needs of dancers, actors, athletes and musiciansâ€”those whose livelihoods depend on achieving and maintaining peak performance. The occasional nutrition-based workshop is offered, as are family-centric music and arts soirees.

address.cross_streets: between Wolcott Ave and Wood St

text.content: If there were such a thing as a pain-free Brazilian wax, you'd find it here ($50). Alas, no such thing exists, but Trim comes pretty damn close. Before mercilessly ripping out your hair, the aestheticians rub oil on your skin, softening it prior to waxing. We tried it once, and now we'll never let anyone wax us before applying the much-needed oil beforehand. It makes the difference between a hair-raising nightmare and a painful but manageable treatment. The spa offers a multitude of hair-removal services, from full face threading to back waxing. Brides-to-be can even ask for “I Do” to get their hoo-has bedazzled. Sparkle isn't reserved just for the ring finger anymore.
El: Red, Brown, Green, Orange, Pink, Purple (rush hrs) to State/Lake; Blue to Washington

text.content: The movie Gone in 60 Seconds blaring on a big screen TV isn't exactly the most soothing thing to encounter on a Saturday morning before a spa service, but hey, this place is strictly for the guys and loud action movies seem to be part of the deal. Thankfully, once you escape Nic Cage stealing someone's car, you have nothing else to worry about here. From the tranquil changing room to the waiting area with a relaxing koi tank, the actual spa area is very soothing. Standout services include The Rubb, a 60-minute massage with your choice of deep tissue or Swedish versions ($90), and even one-on-one private yoga classes ($80 per session). While you're there, don't forget to visit the salon side for the “The Man, which includes a shampoo, cut, paraffin hand wax, hand massage and facial toner ($44).
El: Orange, Green to Roosevelt/Wabash; Red to Roosevelt/State. Bus: 1, 3, X3, 4, X4, 6, 7, 10, 14, 26, 28, 126, 145, 146, 147

The iconic clock at State and Washington, the Frango mintsÂ­â€”yes, we know they’re not made here anymoreand the magnificent Tiffany dome you can see up close from the 5th floor are just a few of the attractions that make this department store, one of the largest in the world, a must-see. The shopping here is divine, offering everything from modestly priced pots and pans to the latest in high-end fashion.Holiday-themed window displays go up every November, and you can take self-guided audio tours of the store year round.

opening_hours.general_remark: Closed Christmas Day and Thanksgiving Day

text.content: El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 22, 36, 72

price.price_type: members, kids under 12 and Mondays free
