address.identifier: The Spa at the Carlton Club

text.content: Elegance and sophistication abound at this spa, which is housed inside the Ritz-Carlton. It (annoyingly) decided that you can't get a treatment here unless you are a guest at the hotel, but the services on offer are so good, they're worth the night at the (not-too-shabby) Ritz. Try the Punta Mita massage (85 minutes for $185), which uses tequila and sage to cleanse and detoxify the body, leaving you tipsy with health. While the treatments are expensive, the added perks at every turn make you feel like you're getting your money's worth. Everyone who uses the spa gets to spend the rest of the day in the gorgeous pool, Jacuzzi, steam room and sauna. If you're motivated, you could also use the fitness center. You'll also be treated to complimentary coffee, tea and juice.

Connected to the populist Excalibur in a castlelike former churchâ€”but marketed separatelyâ€”the expansive Vision has multiple rooms of varying size (the dome, sky and the penthouse) where DJs pump out different styles, from trance to techno to hip-hop. There’s a house event Fridays except the first of the month. Celeb-connected promotions alternate with visits from big-name electronic stars
El: Orange, Green to Roosevelt/Wabash. Bus: 1, 3, 4, 18, 29, 62

Guilt trip warning: In order to get to your massage here, you must first walk through the Holmes Place Health Club (and all the people working out in it), an experience that can easily make you feel like a slacker. Luckily, all anxieties evaporate once you enter this friendly spa, where massages are considered both therapy and relaxation. Atheletes with sore muscles will appreciate the knowledge of masseurs, who may take a whole hour to work on your calves (with your permission, of course). And for those who aren't sore at all, the massages will rid you of all anxieties, and nothingâ€”not even the sight of thirty people working out harder than youâ€”will bother you for the rest of the day.

address.cross_streets: between Fulton Market and Lake St
address.remark: used to be ebersb9 at 1359 W Chicago

text.content: Intimacy and coziness reign at Purity, where owner Michelle Woodard has converted two two-bedroom apartments into one giant living room. The space is obviously designed as an apartment rather than a spa, but facial, massage, nail, changing and relaxation rooms are all outfitted with soothing music, soft sheets, plush robes and homey touches like a snack basket. The menu is thorough and the prices are reasonable, but the spa parties are easily the best deal: For $75 a head, each guest enjoys a 45-minute pedicure and the choice between a 30-minute massage or a 30-minute facial.

address.cross_streets: between Cornelia Ave and Eddy St

address.name: Spa Nordstrom
address.cross_streets: between Wabash Ave and Rush St

text.content: Expect a full-sensory retreat from stress during your visit. All massages and face or body treatments begin the same way: After changing into a cushy robe and slippers, you’re directed to the relaxation area, a dimly lit room with scented candles that get you in the mood for an herbal foot soak as you sip tea. Seven treatment rooms are on standby for luxurious services that range in style from East to West. Top that off with a tall glass of one of six elixir tonics.

Chicago nightlife impresario Billy Dec unveiled this bomb shelterâ€“themed spot to no shortage of hype in 2007. For the most part, it lives up to expectations. With populist hip-hop and house remixes from DJ White Shadow, the sleek, dark, militaristic space comes alive. Celebrity command performances might not always be A-list, but the service here impresses.
El: Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Sedgwick. Bus: 72, 156

prices.ticket_reference: Guided tours Sat 2pm, included with admission. Call ext 3130 for reservations.

text.content: El: Red to Lake; Orange, Pink, Green, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Randolph. Bus: 3, X3, 4, X4, 6, 10, 14, 26, 143, 144, 145, 146, 147, 151, 157. Metra: Elec Main to Millennium Station

This laid-back pizza-and-beer joint with a sidewalk patio might seem like an unlikely hot spot for house music, but that’s Chicago for ya. DJs spin almost every day of the week here. In warmer months, the Mamby dance night starts after work and features hometown house favorites and food specials.

We'd never been taught yoga by a tattooed bright-orange haired man wearing tiny shorts (which threatened to reveal a not-so-om part of his body) before we took a class at Yoga Circle before, but that was just an introduction to the alternative teaching style in this studio. Located in a cozy nook on the second floor of an office building, Yoga Circle is just warm enough to make you want to curl up and take a nap. But the teachers here insist on giving you a challenging practice, and they'll stand by your side until you get it right. In fact, the only time the room was quiet was in the last five minutes of our class, when the lights were off. We learned more in this class than ever before.

address.identifier: Spa at the Four Seasons Hotel
address.cross_streets: between Lake Shore Dr and Ernst Ct

text.content: The services are divine here: We melted into a puddle of relaxation after the hour-long massage ($150). But it's the environment that feels extra luxurious. The changing areas have fancy amenities like plush robes, a eucalyptus steam room and oodles of beauty products for postservice primping. Plus, you can upgrade your experience for an extra $30, which allows you to crash the pool and lounge center. (The fee includes access to the fitness center, if you're feeling ambitious.) Swim some laps, laze around on the lounge chairs, or sample the full spread of coffees, teas, and fruit and cookies. It's as close as you'll come to feeling like a trust fund kid.

address.sort_string: Spa at the Four Seasons Hotel

text.content: El: Red, Brown, Purple (rush hrs) to Chicago. Bus: 11, 22, 36, 66, 145, 147, 173

While nudity-shy spagoers will appreciate the ankle-length kimono provided by Japanese Spa Zen, anyone with a knotted back or an empty wallet will love the moderately priced relief provided by the Amma Massage ($65 for 60 minutes). The traditional Asian style of massage uses kneading, pressing and pulling (rather than surface strokes) to remove energy blockages. Naoko Luppescu, who co-owns the spa with her husband, Stuart, learned the technique in her native Japan. She begins the treatment at the feet and ends at the base of the skull, skimming the body with a soothing combination of firm pressing and gentle squeezing. The environs aren't cushy and we recommend skipping the nail services (our pedi was done in lukewarm water and the aesthetician couldn't be bothered with smudges), but for a massage, it's worth a try.
Bus: 55, 59, 170. Metra: Elec Main to 59th St
